lexUnit.name: feign.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: pretend to be affected by.

sentence.text: Corbett rubbed his eyes wearily , feigning to be more exhausted than he really was .

Durie was scheduled to fight an FA charge of misconduct after referee Dermot Gallagher alleged he feigned being head-butted in a confrontation with Andy Pearce in a game against Coventry on August 18 .
The Spurs striker is alleged to have feigned being head-butted by Coventry 's Andy Pearce .
I asked Francis questions and I 'm not sure my nonchalance was feigned .
` Come on now , Ali , " she complains , knowing he likes to feign death .
Some poets feign their wounds and scars ;
I feigned lack of interest and made to go .
Blanche decided to feign stupidity so that the Commander could patronise her and she might discover how and why Spittals had been looking into her investigation behind her back .
She feigned enthusiasm , but what she was really thinking was that she 'd been a fool to hope he 'd come here on a more personal mission .
Merrill opened a drawer at random , took out a file and feigned immediate interest in its contents .
He put his hands to his temples , feigning weariness .
Valerie 's irritation , whether actual or feigned , is linked to expression in Creole .
` Hello , " Ken called back , feigning the appearance of what looked very much like a smile .
` Unfortunately , " Charity said , unable to feign complete indifference to the topic , ` I suspect the more he rejects her , the more her self-esteem becomes tied up in winning him over . "
We feigned not to grasp the reference , though Durham City readers may understand it very well .
He then used skills honed in half a lifetime as a successful actor to feign shock and sorrow , said Mr Calvert-Smith .
